about.ai: The development process of the Komari project has been assisted by artificial intelligence tools. These tools are used for tasks such as code generation, refactoring, and debugging to improve development efficiency and code quality. All AI-generated code and suggestions have been reviewed and validated by human developers.
about.open_source: Komari is open source under the MIT license and is built using the following open source software:
about.title: About

nodeTable.autoRenewalDescription: If the server expires and is currently online, Komari will automatically set the expiration time to the next natural month (year)
nodeTable.billingCycleTips:
Billing Cycle Rules

By Preset Cycle (Calendar Renewal)
When the number of days entered is close to the preset plan (such as monthly, quarterly, annually), it will renew according to the corresponding calendar cycle.
- Common values: 30 (monthly), 92 (quarterly), 365 (annually), 730 (biennially), etc.
- Example: Entering 30, the service renews on March 15, and the new expiration date will be April 15.

By Custom Days
When other numbers of days are entered (such as 7, 45, 100), it will strictly renew according to the number of days.
- Example: Entering 45, the service renews on March 15, and the new expiration date will be April 29 (45 days later).

One-time Payment
Entering -1 indicates a one-time payment.

notification.expire_enable_description: If enabled, the system will send reminder notifications before expiration.
notification.expire_time_description: Set how many days in advance to start sending reminder notifications before expiration.
notification.login_description: Send a notification when a new session logs into Komari.
notification.traffic_description: Komari will send notifications when the server reaches the specified percentage of traffic usage, with reminders at 5% increments. If no traffic threshold is set, no notifications will be sent. Set to 0 to disable traffic reminders.

chart.cutPeak_tips:
Tips on Data Smoothing

When you enable smoothing, the curves you see in the statistical charts are processed using the Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) algorithm, a commonly used data smoothing technique.


It's important to note that the values displayed by the EWMA algorithm's smoothed curves, are not the original, raw measured data. They represent a smoothed trend line calculated based on the EWMA algorithm, designed to reduce data fluctuations and make data patterns and trends easier to identify.


Therefore, the values you see are more of a visual presentation, helping you better understand the overall direction and long-term trends of the data, rather than the precise true value at each point in time. If you need to view specific, raw data points, please refer to the unsmoothed data view.
chart.loss_tips: Packet loss rate calculation algorithms are inaccurate; please use with caution. Vol(volatility): The tail fluctuation of latency, the higher the value, the greater the fluctuation, calculation method: (P99 - P50) / max(min(P50, 50), 10).

To prevent frequent notifications, we use a grace period:
Grace Period: If a client goes offline and doesn't reconnect within this time, an offline notification will be sent.
